p: Poultry products are particularly prone to oxidative deterioration due to their high concentrations of polyunsaturated fatty acids. The reviews by Lee et al. (2003) and Khan et al. (2012) showed that thyme oil is effective in retarding oxidant degradation in poultry-derived products, such as meat and eggs. The possible reason might be the antioxidant activity derived from the phenolic OH group which acts as a donor of hydrogen interacting with peroxy radicals during the initial process in lipid oxidation and thereby inhibiting or retarding the hydroxyl peroxide formation ( Lee et al., 2003). There was a linear relationship between the amount of total phenols and antioxidant capacity of medicinal plants ( Fig. 1). Rosemary, oregano, and sage of the Labiate family were also reported for their effective antioxidant activities in broiler meat ( Brenes and Roura, 2010, Franz et al., 2010, Windisch et al., 2008). Regarding the metabolic fate of essential oils in poultry, the research is still lacking. Kohlert et al. (2000) reported that the metabolic fates of essential oils are chemical structure depended; essential oil components are quickly eliminated; and accumulation is unlikely due to the high clearance and short half-lives in human, which lends support to no residue of essential oils in animal products.
